Single RDO without dependencies

Source: vignettes/a01_single-rdo-without-dependencies.Rmd
a01_single-rdo-without-dependencies.Rmd

Creating a Reproducible Data Object (RDO)

Let’s create a single RDO without any dependencies. Our ROD object will be encapsulating mtcars dataset under different name data_mtcars and the reproducible R code.

# library(RDO)
data_mtcars <- RDO::RDO$new(name = "data_mtcars")

data_mtcars
#> <RDO>
#> Name: data_mtcars 
#> Dependencies: none.
#> Status:
#> - created:        2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last changed:   2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last touched:   (never) 
#> - last validated: (never) 
#> - last run time:   
#> - run time total: 0 
#> - is validated?   FALSE 
#> - is locked?      FALSE 
#> - cache size:     0 Mb 
#> - cached total:   0 Mb

Printing the object gives you the name of the object, dependencies if there are any, and statuses.

Let’s add the reproducible code. The code needs to be of expression class. We need simply to wrap our code in expression({ }).

data_mtcars$code <- expression({
  data_mtcars <- mtcars
})

data_mtcars
#> <RDO>
#> Name: data_mtcars 
#> Dependencies: none.
#> Status:
#> - created:        2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last changed:   2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last touched:   2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last validated: (never) 
#> - last run time:   
#> - run time total: 0 
#> - is validated?   FALSE 
#> - is locked?      FALSE 
#> - cache size:     0 Mb 
#> - cached total:   0 Mb

If we changing the code or the cached data the timestamp last changed is updated. Reading the cache changes the last touched timestamp, so we know when the RDO was last used.

We can access the cached data via active binding cache.

data_mtcars$cache
#> NULL

The cache is NULL as the code has never been run yet and the data haven’t been cached yet. Let’s do it for the first time…

Running the RDO R code

data_mtcars$run()
#> Evaluating RDO: data_mtcars ... done!
#> ...evaluation of data_mtcars completed.

If we don’t want to see messages printed out to the console we can turn it off in RDO methods using verbose parameter (default is TRUE).

data_mtcars$run(verbose = FALSE)

head(data_mtcars$cache)
#>                    mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb
#> Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4
#> Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4
#> Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1
#> Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1
#> Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2
#> Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1

data_mtcars
#> <RDO>
#> Name: data_mtcars 
#> Dependencies: none.
#> Status:
#> - created:        2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last changed:   2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last touched:   2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last validated: 2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last run time:  0.0170009136199951 
#> - run time total: 0.0170009136199951 
#> - is validated?   TRUE 
#> - is locked?      FALSE 
#> - cache size:     0.0069 Mb 
#> - cached total:   0.0069 Mb

Now the data cache is available. We can see how big is the size of the RDO cache.

Implicit validation

After the code was evaluated and the result was cached, the status is validated? changed to TRUE. This is called implicit validation. We can confirm it with is_validated() method.

data_mtcars$is_validated()
#> RDO: 'data_mtcars' is validated.
#> [1] TRUE

Chaining the RDO methods

Many of RDO methods return self object so we can chain them.

data_mtcars$run()$is_validated()
#> Evaluating RDO: data_mtcars ... done!
#> ...evaluation of data_mtcars completed.
#> RDO: 'data_mtcars' is validated.
#> [1] TRUE

RDO getters

We can access the name of the RDO using get_name() method.

data_mtcars$get_name()
#> [1] "data_mtcars"

The get_status method returns the list of different statuses.

data_mtcars$get_status()
#> $name
#> [1] "data_mtcars"
#> 
#> $created
#> [1] "2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC"
#> 
#> $changed
#> [1] "2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC"
#> 
#> $touched
#> [1] "2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC"
#> 
#> $validated
#> [1] "2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC"
#> 
#> $is_validated
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $is_locked
#> [1] FALSE
#> 
#> $run_time
#> Time difference of 0 secs
#> 
#> $run_time_total
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $cache_size
#> 7208 bytes
#> 
#> $cache_size_total
#> 7208 bytes

Getting the code

To access the code as a text we can use code active binding. It returns the RDO (self) but before that it prints out to the console the RDO code.

data_mtcars$code
#> <RDO code>
#> data_mtcars <- mtcars
#> <RDO>
#> Name: data_mtcars 
#> Dependencies: none.
#> Status:
#> - created:        2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last changed:   2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last touched:   2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last validated: 2020-03-09 13:59:47 UTC 
#> - last run time:  0 
#> - run time total: 0 
#> - is validated?   TRUE 
#> - is locked?      FALSE 
#> - cache size:     0.0069 Mb 
#> - cached total:   0.0069 Mb

The print_code() method can give you similar effect.

data_mtcars$print_code()
#> data_mtcars <- mtcars

If you want to get your code as R expressions you can use get_code() method. The returned expression can be than evaluated manually. You can also use run_code(cache = FALSE) method for that purpose. The code will be evaluated but result will not be cached.

data_mtcars$get_code()
#> expression(data_mtcars = {
#>     data_mtcars <- mtcars
#> })

eval_result <- eval(data_mtcars$get_code(), envir = new.env())
head(eval_result)
#>                    mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb
#> Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4
#> Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4
#> Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1
#> Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1
#> Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2
#> Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1

head(data_mtcars$run(cache = FALSE))
#> Evaluating RDO: data_mtcars ... done!
#> ...evaluation of data_mtcars completed.
#>                    mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb
#> Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4
#> Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4
#> Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1
#> Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1
#> Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2
#> Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1

Locking an RDO

You can reset your cache to by setting its value to NULL, but you cannot do it if the RDO is locked.

data_mtcars$cache <- NULL

data_mtcars$run()$lock()$is_locked()
#> Evaluating RDO: data_mtcars ... done!
#> ...evaluation of data_mtcars completed.
#> Locking RDO: 'data_mtcars' ... done.
#> RDO: 'data_mtcars' is LOCKED!
#> [1] TRUE

data_mtcars$cache <- NULL
#> Error in (function (value) : This RDO is locked! Cannot overwrite the RDO's cache.

data_mtcars$unlock()
#> Unlocking RDO: 'data_mtcars' ... done.

Explicit validation

Running the code and caching the result implicitly validating the RDO, but there is also an explicit validation. Explicit Validation is done using validate() method. The method is evaluating the reproducible code and the result is compare to the cached data. If they are the same, the RDO is validated.

data_mtcars$cache <- iris

data_mtcars$validate()$is_validated()
#> Validating RDO: 'data_mtcars' ... NOT validated!
#> RDO: 'data_mtcars' is NOT VALIDATED!
#> [1] FALSE

data_mtcars$cache <- mtcars

data_mtcars$validate()$is_validated()
#> Validating RDO: 'data_mtcars' ... done.
#> RDO: 'data_mtcars' is validated.
#> [1] TRUE
